title: britains got talent investor liam collins faces of disco
story: Liam Collins - who starred in the hit ITV show as one half of the Faces of Disco dance duo - went bust after his student accommodation firm collapsed.Semi-finalist Liam, , ran the business with cousin David Bone, .The pair are each facing up to six years in jail after being found guilty of swindling nine investors out of up to £, each.After losing millions on their -property portfolio, they set up a near-identical company that tricked investors by ly claimed to have signed a £m business deal.They promised the cash would be used to invest in more buy-to-let accomodation - but used it to underwrite debts on the other company.The pair also claimed to have launched an audacious bid to buy Michael Jacksons Neverland ranch for £m.At the time the investigation Collins said: We are not conmen and there was never any intention of misleading anyone.I’m incredibly sympathetic to the investors - a lot of them are my own family members - but it’s a two-way relationship you can be an irresponsible businessman but you can also be an irresponsible investor.Some people think I’m walking around like a millionaire, with money stashed in an offshore account and these people would like me dead.But I’ve lost everything, £m,  houses, my cars my friends, everything.At Manchester Crown Court, Collins, from Springfield Park, Newcastle and Bone from Astley, near Wigan admitted fraudulent trading.Both will be sentenced tomorrow but prosecutors have asked for imprisonment between three and six years.

title: brexit tory leadership dominic raab no deal
story: The Brexiteer refused to rule out using the nuclear option of dissolving the Commons to ensure Britain leaves the EU on October .Mr Raab suggested he may prorogue Parliament so pro-Remain MPs cant pass a law delaying or cancelling Brexit.The incendiary move came in a second Tory leadership hustings in Westminster.Backbencher Antoinette Sandbach said the comment was met with a “deathly silence” in a room of  MPs.And Amber Rudd stormed: “It is outrageous to consider proroguing Parliament.”Rory Stewart, an outside contender for No, blasted: You can try to lock the gates of Parliament. But to do so for this purpose would be unlawful.Pro-EU Commons Speaker John Bercow told MPs: Parliament will not be evacuated from the centre stage of the decision-making process on this important matter. That is simply not going to happen.Both rivals Michael Gove - who says he could delay Brexit beyond October  - and Matt Hancock ruled out the idea.Mr Hancock sent a letter to all candidates today, saying: To suspend Parliament explicitly to pursue a course of action against its wishes is not a serious policy of a Prime Minister in the st century.He called on the other contenders to join him in pledging never to prorogue the Commons for political ends.Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt didn’t rule it out – but said it wouldn’t work. And he joked the last time anybody tried to dissolve Parliament, it led to the English civil war.Mr Hunt last night hailed his entrepreneurial skills and experience as Foreign Secretary as the reason why he was the best candidate to get a Brexit deal done.And he insisted he wasn’t “Theresa in trousers” as he hit back at those claiming he would simply carry on with Theresa May’s policies.He told MPs: “There is a deal here and we have a responsibility to find it. If we go to the EU and put a gun to their head they’re going to walk.”Mr Hunt, the leading Remainer in the race, could get the key endorsement of Ms Rudd in the coming days.A source close to her suggested she was likely to back him but was also considering Mr Gove and Mr Hancock.Today Andrea Leadsom laid out her Brexit plan - vowing to step up No Deal preparations and confront Brussels.June : Nominations for the leadership open am-pm candidates must have the support of eight MPsJune : First ballot of MPs, open am-pm any candidate with fewer than  votes eliminatedJune : Second ballot , open pm-pm any candidate with fewer than  votes eliminatedJune : Third ballot , open pm-pm candidate with fewest votes eliminatedJune : Fourth ballot , open am-pm candidate with fewest votes eliminatedJune : Second stage begins where votes sht from MPs to party activists who will choose between final two candidatesJuly : Result announced this week, in time for Commons recess to beginBoris Johnson got a boost as Remainer MP Damian Collins endorsed his campaign, saying: In these challenging times, I believe that a dynamic force is a very necessary thing.And Sajid Javid secured the backing of top Brexiteer Digby Jones, former head of the CBI business group.But outsider Sam Gyimah slammed rivals who claim they can get a better Brexit deal than Theresa May, accusing them of Trumpian machismo.

story: “Is that it ” “Seriously ” “ grand ” “For one of that lot ”Never was it more true than the th and most sentimental series yet of Britain’s Got Talent, where the major talking point of last week’s live shows should’ve been Simon Cowell’s hair, which had been dyed a vivid shade of gorilla haemorrhoid black for the occasion.One David Walliams barb and a death stare from the boss, though, made it clear the subject was very much “off limits”.And Cowell probably had a point, as well.He knows that unless the judges act like the most credulous, gushing, “upped-your-game” morons in the theatre, then the whole show unravels.Nothing new there, obviously. It’s been like that since series one.It’s just that this year’s contestants forced them to be even more credulous, gushing and moronic than usual.Particularly the magicians, who were all doing iations on the same trick, with such little stagecraft, that one of last year’s rejects, Marc Spelmann, was deemed best of the bunch by virtue of putting on his X mask and saying nothing.It didn’t end there, however.Critical faculties also had to be suspended for a procession of try-hard comedians, pub singers, sob stories, village fete dancers and that Haunting thing which had Amanda Holden gasping, panting, yelping “F***” and Simon claiming: “It sounded like being next door to you on honeymoon.”Though probably not the fortnight inside Les Dennis’s static caravan in Rhyl.It wasn’t all bad, naturally.Someone almost held a tune, I’m sure, and there was a bit more tension to Jonathan Goodwin’s “Blindfold chick- en with crossbow”than there was about the Gomonov bird, who kept ducking out of the way almost every time her mate threw a kne.But what BGT really needs in such circumstances are dingbats like Gonzo, the fat Japanese tambourine frenzy, and Guy First, the Israeli bloke who can hand-fart the opening verse and chorus of We Will Rock You.He was born to be on this show, in fact, which makes what Alesha Dixon did during his semi-final appearance even more of a sackable offence. She buzzed him.She actually buzzed State Of The Fart, claiming he was “funny”, but she was “thinking rationally”.A very bad idea. Think rationally, Alesha, luv, and you might as well pack up and go home now, because the nut-fudge fringe acts are one of only two reasons this carnival of the mediocre is still going after  series.The other, of course, is the hosts, Ant  Dec, who may have fluffed the odd line but they never gushed or patronised, let alone talked down to the eventual winner, Colin Thackery.It was a majestic performance that came with a slightly unwelcome sting in the tail, on Sunday night, from Ant.“There’s a very special new show coming up later in the year, Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions. The finest acts from the last  years will compete against the best acts from around the world.” Dec: “Have they got a host yet ”Sell every share in the project immediately,ITV hasn’t got them both nailed down on five-year contracts. INCIDENTALLY,you watch only two shows this week, make them tonight’s finale of Chernobyl, on Sky Atlantic, at pm, and Harry Hill’s Alien Fun Capsule, Saturday, ITV, .pm, which features Oscar-nominated actor Sir Tom Courtenay playing “Michael Rodwell – blow ya top,” with Les Dennis.Gary Neville: “Both City and Liverpool have won  games, Liverpool ten games.”And Neil Mellor: “I wouldn’t say it was luck, but Spurs were certainly fortunate.”AND the  Soap Award for Most Hastily Arranged Holiday goes to . . .EastEnders’ Sharon Mitchell, who’d bought her tickets, sorted her visa, packed and headed off for Heathrow within  seconds of having the idea to go to Australia, last year.Just one of the many amazing storylines not honoured at the st Awards, hosted by Phillip Schofield, in Manchester, which someone on the red carpet described as a “Very Hollywood” occasion.Yeah, very. Even , to the best of my knowledge, The Oscars has never had a Best Bitch category.It’s no longer part of these ITV awards, sadly, and the ceremony’s gone all worthy, making the usual disapproving noises about sexism, championing mental health campaigns and acknowledging Hollyoaks’ Jack Reynolds, who’s set to become the oldest soap star ever, at , beating the previous record set by Corrie’s Bev Callard, who’s about .In another break with tradition, the Soap Awards had the chance to honour a genuinely brilliant episode of EastEnders, Shaki’s funeral, which movingly combined the character’s death with real-le victims of kne crime.I need hardly tell you, then, it lost the Scene of the Year category to an entirely forgettable Gail monologue from Coronation Street.The biggest missed opportunity of the night, however, possibly came with the “very special” gong for a member of the Emmerdale family.“She’s a faultless pro. . . one of the show’s finest ambassadors. . .  paved the way for female colleagues. So the Tony Warren award goes to. . .”Roxanne Pallett for Celebrity Bi. . .“Val Lawson.”Oh, OK. Maybe next year then HIGHLIGHT of the television week was arguably Gwyneth Paltrow’s spirit guide, Shaman Durek, attempting to perform “a healing process” on This Morning’s host Eamonn Holmes.Not a one-man job, by any stretch of the ­imagination.After a brief bit of finger clicking and some new-age waffle, though, Eamonn was sedated and Durek was commanding the spirits to “go into the access point in his stomach”, before asking: “Is there anything the spirits need ”Is there ever, Durek.Spirits, would you like a JCB Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dwp quietly hands private firms
story: NewsDWP quietly hands private firms £m extra to test disabled people for benefitsEXCLUSIVE: Atos and Maximus had their PIP and ESA contracts extended for the second time despite accusations theyre running a "failing" welfare system. Now the eye-watering cost to taxpayers can be revealedShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsA stock photo of an elderly woman in a wheelchair "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory ministers are quietly handing private firms an extra £million to test sick and disabled people for benefits - despite an avalanche of complaints. Welfare chiefs are accused of rewarding failure after they extended contracts with corporate giants Atos and Maximus without going out to tender. The firmsapos deals to assess people for Personal Independence Paymentsand Employment and Support Allowancewere each extended in recent months to July . Now the eye-watering cost has been confirmed by the Department for Work and Pensions, which slipped the details online without fanfare late last Friday. The documents said extending Atosapos PIP contract by two years would cost taxpayers up to £.m, while the ESA contract - run by a subsidiary of Maximus - would cost up to £.m for a -month extension. In total, DWP chiefs have approved up to £.m on the two contracts put together.  It was the second time each firm had its contract extended by the DWP despite an outcry over the failing privately-run tests. Last June Atos was warned to start delivering or  by MPs on the powerful Work and Pensions Committee. And % of ESA tests and % of PIP tests that went to appeal in the last three months of  were overturned, the highest rate on record. Yet the corporate giants will now have enjoyed their lucrative contracts for eight and seven years respectively by the time they finally come up for renewal. The DWP said the contracts were extended to ensure stability while it redesigns the assessment process to make it better for claimants long term. When she announced the move in March, DWP chief Amber Rudd argued it would pave the way for a more joined-up claimant experience in future. But Genevieve Edwards, of the MS Society, branded the extensions a kick in the teeth for people claiming PIP for the painful and exhausting condition.  She said: Weaposve been told all too frequently that assessors donapost understand MS and the process doesnapost capture the reality of living with it. Itaposs nonsensical to reward this lack of understanding and failing system with extra millions of pounds, when what is really needed is an overhaul so people donapost have to fight to get the support they need. Atos delivers the majority of PIP assessments under the name Independent Assessment Servicesthrough a contract it has held since . ESA assessments have been delivered since October  by a firm called The Centre for Health and Disability Assessments Ltd- whose parent corporation is US outsourcing giant Maximus.  Capita also has a PIP assessments contract, which is also being extended, but talks are ongoing over the details. Labouraposs Shadow Minister for Disabled People Marsha De Cordova said: It is scandalous that hundreds of millions of pounds more have been handed over to private companies, such as Atos and CHDA, that are wreaking havoc on disabled people’s lives. By extending these contracts, this Tory government has once again shown its disregard for the appalling inaccuracies of outsourced assessments for PIP and ESA, which have had a devastating impact on so many disabled people. Labour will end the hostile environment that these assessments have created and bring them in house. The data was uploaded last Friday to the DWPaposs website but then removed on Monday - following the Mirroraposs enquiries - with officials claiming parts were inaccurate. Despite the removal a DWP spokeswoman told the Mirror today that the data was in fact accurate. Itaposs understood the price tag is a maximum budget and could end up being less. A DWP spokeswoman confirmed: “These figures refer to the previously announced extensions of the PIP and HDAS contracts to , and not to any additional extensions or new costs.  We’re committed to providing the best possible service for disabled people, which is why we’re continually improving the assessment process for PIP and ESA. We regularly monitor our assessment providers to ensure they are delivering against the high standards we expect.” A spokesman for CHDA, whose parent firm is Maximus, said, “We are pleased to be continuing our partnership with DWP to deliver the Health Assessment Advisory Service. Since taking over the service we have fundamentally improved the experience for those we assess.  The time spent in the assessment process has more than halved, we have doubled the number of clinical staff working in the service and consistently met the majority of our performance targets. We will continue to work in partnership with charities and disabled people’s organisations to improve the service further.” A spokesman for Atosapos IAS said: “We are absolutely committed to providing a professional and compassionate service for every claimant. And as we continue to work with the DWP and listen to all feedback with a clear focus on achieving this, we shall also make continuous improvements.”

story: NewsTory leadership contest turns nasty as candidates trade insults -  of the worstNominations havent even opened yet but the race to be next Prime Minister has already turned nastyShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video tory-leadership-race-who--,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was only a matter of time before the Tory leadership race turned ugly. Nominations open and close on Monday to be Britainaposs next Prime Minister - and already the insults are flying. Splits have emerged over everything from Brexit to schools and Labour anti-Semitism. The  candidates are jostling for the backing of their fellow Tory MPs, whoaposll narrow the field down to just two by the end of June. Thataposs sparked a desperate search for support - since MPs without  backers will be automatically eliminated next Thursday. Theyaposll then go to a ballot of , Tory members whoaposll install the UKaposs next leader by July . Here are  of the most dramatic spats just in the last  hours. If we did them all weaposd be here all day...    Michael Gove launched a barely-veiled attack on arch-rival Boris Johnson, who he kned out of the last leadership race three years ago. In a barb at the gaffe-prone Brexiteer, Mr Gove said MPs need someone who is serious about the job at hand. And he took aim at Mr Johnsonaposs claim that Theresa Mayaposs Brexit deal would make the UK a vassal state. The Environment Secretary said: I think it demeans language to use words like vassal state. People use words like vassal state and treachery, traitor. You are not a traitoryou disagree with me about Europe. He also said Boris Johnsonaposs refusal to delay Brexit beyond October  could force a general election that thrusts Jeremy Corbyn into  Downing Street.    Dominic Raab sparked fury with an illegal plot to ram through No Deal Brexit - by SHUTTING the House of Commons. A huge row erupted after Dominic Raab refused to rule out proroguing Parliament to prevent MPs voting against No Deal on October . Mr Raab, a hard Brexiteer, said he would be prepared to take the drastic move at a behind-closed-doors hustings last night. But pro-EU Cabinet minister Amber Rudd - whoaposs not standing but is considered a aposkingmakerapos for moderate MPs - raged: Itaposs outrageous to consider proroguing Parliament. We are not Stuart kings. And pro-EU leadership rival Rory Stewart said the move would be illegal adding: It would be unconstitutional. It would be undemocratic. And it wouldnapost work.  MPs like Michael Gove have been saying theyaposd be prepared to delay Brexit to get a deal through. And several seem to think they can do better than Theresa May at getting a deal - among them Jeremy Hunt and Matt Hancock. But anti-Brexit rival Sam Gyimah, the only candidate to back a second referendum, hit back. He branded those who thought they were better than Mrs May chest-beating men driven by Trumpian machismo. He told Bloomberg: You’ve got chest-beating men saying they could do what Theresa May failed to do. “They’re saying they could go and renegotiate in a Trump way and get a better deal.”    Dominic Raab came eye-to-eye with Chancellor Philip Hammond in a private hustings last night. A source in the room said the arch-Brexiteer turned to the pro-EU rival and attacked his strategy from just a few feet away. According to the source he was asked what the worst mistake of the previous government was. He turned, cold-eyed, to pro-EU Chancellor Philip Hammond at last nightaposs event and said Brits were sick of Brexit aposProject Fearapos.  Brexiteer outrider Esther McVey attacked Michael Gove - who as Education Secretary went to war with teachers - by saying the Tories must listen to school staff. And she blamed that failure to listen for the Tories losing votes. She wrote in The Times: It’s time we started listening to the teaching unions and teachers on the frontline. The Conservative Party has lost the votes of many teachers in recent years, largely because they believed we weren’t listening to them. This must change. If we, as a party, are not prepared to listen to what teachers and their unions are telling us about where the shortfalls are and what our priorities should be, we can’t properly claim to be a party that takes our children’s education seriously. She also vowed yesterday to sack any Remainers in the Cabinet in a purge to ensure Brexit happens on time.  This one isnapost a blue-on-blue attack, but itaposs so shocking we deemed it worthy of inclusion. Tory leadership candidate Matt Hancock was branded “a desparate no-hoper” last night after accusing Jeremy Corbyn of anti-semitism. In a controversial pitch to win over Tory MPs, the health secretary launched a savage personal attack on the Labour leader. He told a Westminster hustings that unless the Tories sorted themselves out on Brexit they would lose to Labour at the next election. In remarks clearly intended to raise his profile among party members, he added: “The Conservative party has got to get this right. “If we don’t, we could end up with the first anti-semitic leader of a Western nation since the Second World War.” Shadow chancellor John McDonnell, a close Corbyn ally, said the Tory minister’s remarks were “a disgrace” as he walked past moments later. Labour chairman Ian Lavery told the Mirror: “It’s desperate remarks from a desperate no-hoper who will say anything to try and achieve power. Hancock should concentrate his efforts on the Tories potential sell off of our cherished NHS to Trump and his cronies.” A Labour source added: “This baseless political attack rings hollow from a minister in a party that has supported governments that actively promote antisemitic policies in Hungary and Poland, and has spent the week wooing Trump”.

story: NewsTory leadership: MPs face having their phones seized in anti-cheating crackdownConservative chiefs drew parallels with elections in Turkey and Bosnia as they announced ultra-strict security in the vote to choose our next Prime MinisterShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video tory-leadership-race-who--,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory MPs face having their phones seized during the leadership election to replace Theresa May in a hardline anti-cheating crackdown. Party chiefs are mulling the extreme measure to stop Tory MPs taking photos of the ballot paper to choose the next PM - which itaposs feared could be hijacked and copied. Even veteran MPs and Cabinet ministers will have to show security-cleared ID before they vote - and the colour of ballot papers will only be decided the night before. The rules were unveiled today by the  Committee of Tory MPs, which is running the first part of the election. MPs will vote up to five or six times to whittle the -strong field of candidates down to two by June . The two final candidates then go to a vote by , Conservative Party members by the end of July. Read the full leadership election timetable here. MPs will vote and the results will be announced in the dark, oak-led Committee Room  in the Victorian Palace of Westminster.    MPs will have to enter through one door at the end of the room, show their parliamentary security passes at the door in order to very they really are a Tory MP. They will then be ticked off a list and handed a ballot paper, which has to be imprinted with a special  Committee stamp to show it is genuine. At that point they will proceed into Committee Room  to vote in a private booth, like in a general election. They must then leave via a separate door in the middle of the committee room. MPs who are away on business can get a proxy vote. But the MP voting on their behalf must be nominated in advance, and run through the entire voting process twice. Ballot boxes will then be taken into a completely off-limits room for votes to be counted,  Committee acting co-chair Dame Cheryl Gillan said.  Dame Cheryl said MPs will absolutely not be allowed to communicate photos of their ballot papers. I monitor international elections, she said. I did Turkey, Iaposve done Bosnia and Herzegovina. There was no photographing of the ballots. Weaposre going to try to prevent it this time, there were MPs that did it last time. They may need to leave their pass and their phone whilst they go and vote. We havenapost decided on that. It is not reasonable to expect the ballot papers to be photographed. If MPs do tweet photos of their ballot papers, Dame Cheryl said, they will incur the wrath of the  executive.    Thoughthey turn up only just before the cut-off time and there is a queue, apos chiefs will be flexible about letting them in to vote. Askedshe didnapost trust Tory MPs, Dame Cheryl said: We do trust our colleagues. But we also have to have a process in which people have confidence. Therefore, as we are in charge of it, we have to go to those s to make sure thereaposs a process everybody in the party does have confidence in. Lined with historic artworks, Parliamentaposs Committee Room  is the same hall where Theresa May survived a no-confidence vote by her own MPs in December. Now it will be used to host the contest for her successor. Results of the first secret ballot on Thursday  June will be announced in alphabetical order at pm. Those with  or fewer votes are knocked out.  Anyone with  or fewer votes is then knocked out in the second ballot on Tuesday  June. Further ballots on June - will then knock out one MP each time until just two remain. Acting co-chair of the committee Charles Walker said: We are aiming to have two people by Thursday June . There is provision for a fth ballot on Thursday June . Iaposm not a mathematical or statistical expert, but I think it would be very dficult... to get beyond a fth ballot in this process. Who knows  We might finish this process before Thursday June . If two candidates in the MPsapos ballot are tied for last place, there will be a discussion with both candidates and the ballot could have to be re-run.  Mr Walker said: Weaposre not going to be drawing lots. I think thataposs a bit extreme. The rules were subject to a last-minute shake-up to add the -MP and -MP thresholds - a move intended to speed up the race when more than a dozen MPs stood.  Committee chiefs defended the last-minute change, insisting the rules had never been set in stone - and are changed before every leadership election. They said the Committee had guidelines on how to set its rules - but refused today to release those guidelines to the public. Mr Walker said because Theresa May only resigns tomorrow, the rules have not officially been changed midway through a leadership contest. He said: The feedback Iaposve had from constituents is aposthank God the  has got a grip of this and is delivering a process in a timely fashionapos. Dame Cheryl added: The President of my association actually contacted me to say how many phone calls sheaposd had, of people saying they were very pleased weaposd agreed the rules. Committee Room  will also host two behind-closed-doors hustings on June - and June . Only Tory MPs will be allowed into the hustings with not even Conservative peers - or the press - allowed in. The Toriesapos DUP allies will not be allowed in either.  Despite open warfare gripping the Tories for months - and every meeting instantly leaking -  acting chair Charles Walker claimed journalists would make MPs terried of speaking their mind. He told reporters bluntly: The fact of the matter is, you do cramp colleaguesapos styles on occasion. We want to have hustings where people can ask questions and express themselves fully. And to be honest, with you sitting in the back of the room Iaposd be pretty terried, and Iaposve been here for a number of years. You are quite a frightening group of people on occasions, and I mean that. Dame Cheryl claimed the room was too small to fit even one pool journalist inside during hustings. She said: Press doesnapost have access to all areas. There are still some things that do remain in private. There are going to be plenty of opportunities for hustings, for you to see the candidates in hustings.  Once two final candidates have been chosen the Toriesapos , members will spend a month deciding who will lead their party. Members will take part in a postal ballot, with a nationwide tour and a huge list of hustings by the candidates expected. There is no electronic voting. Hustings are expected to be held in every single region of the UK and are expected to be open to the press. Nominations open at am and close at pm this coming Monday. MPs must submit their names with a proposer, seconder and six more MP backers to the  Committee. The race is overseen by  Committee acting co-chairs Dame Cheryl Gillan and Charles Walker after chairman Sir Graham Brady quit to mull a leadership bid himself. Neither the five officers of the  Committee nor Tory chairman Brandon Lewis can campaign for a candidate. But they do all get a vote and members of the wider  executive are free to campaign.  Theresa May will remain a lame duck Prime Minister until the end of July after she resigns as leader, through an exchange of letters with the Committee, tomorrow.  She will also continue to be the partyaposs acting leader to avoid an interim leader having to be formally registered with the Electoral Commission. And she will only stop being Prime Minister after going to Buckingham Palace to tell the Queen she is leaving. Downing Street today said she would only leave when she believes someone  can command the confidence of the House. That sparked speculation she could wait until Parliamentaposs summer break, to stop Labour triggering an immediate no-confidence vote in the government. No later claried there was no question of the prime minister hanging around beyond the Conservative leadership contest. But  Committee chiefs today were unable to guarantee the winner of the Tory leadership race will definitely become the next Prime Minister. Dame Cheryl said: Weaposre the ing officers for the election. We produce the result. We donapost deal with what happens in the aftermath. Mr Walker added: I donapost think anybody can say anything with certainty.

title: council officials called grenfell tower
story: NewsCouncil officials called Grenfell Tower area little Africa and refused visitLabour MP Emma Dent Coad said the attitude of Kensington and Cha Council was either racism or snobbery after the fire claimed the lives of  people in June ShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JUN NewsThe fire brigade said  fire engines and  firefighters had been called to the blaze in Grenfell Tower, which has  flats "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCouncil officials called the Grenfell Tower area aposlittle Africaapos and refused to visit the site, according to an MP. Labour MP Emma Dent Coad said the attitude of Kensington and Cha Council was either aposracism or snobberyapos after the fire claimed the lives of  people in June . Speaking as MPs criticised the response to the fire, Ms Dent Coad told the Commons: A senior council officer was told to go down to the site but refused. He said, aposItaposs like little Africa down thereapos. Another said aposthe area was full of people from the Tropicsapos A senior officer regularly in front of others referred to my neighbours as aposmussiesapos.   Ms Dent Coad, a councillor for the London borough, revealed she is also suffering from post-traumatic stress disorderafter the west London blaze, reports the Mail .Kensington and Cha Council said it would write to Ms Dent Coad and investigate the allegations urgently. Ms Dent Coad also spoke about some of the , people affected to ying degrees and how some are still waiting for help. She spoke of several suicides and claimed the type of trauma we have does not go away. Grenfell United campaigners sat in the public gallery listening to the debate while wearing green, the campaign colour.    In a statement, Kensington and Cha Council leader Elizabeth Campbell said: If these claims can be substantiated we will of course investigate them urgently, but I hope Emma would have reported them at the time as both a local councillor and MP. I will be writing to her directly to find out the details of the cases she outlined in the House of Commons. Last month it was claimed ministers have failed to learn the lessons of Grenfell after research showed some fire brigades are so stretched they can only send two fire engines to tackle a high-rise blaze. The Fire Brigades Unionbranded it a “postcode lottery” and accused Fire Minister Nick Hurd of “utter complacency.”    Some  fire engines were mobilised to tackle the West London blaze in June   An FBU survey found two brigades - Durham and North Yorkshire - had just an allocation of just two pumps for a high rise fire. The highest number was seven, but most had allocated just four. At least  residential buildings across the country are wrapped in the same aluminium based flammable cladding which allowed the Grenfell Tower fire to spread so quickly. A government spokesperson said: “Fire and rescue services have the resources they need and we are encouraged that the number of fire safety audits carried out on purpose-built flats of four or more storeys more than doubled, to nearly , in -, compared with the previous year. “We have banned combustible cladding and are fully funding its replacement on high-rise residential buildings in the private and social housing sectors. We have also accepted all the recommendations of the independent Hackitt Review and are working to implement a major overhaul of building and fire safety regulations.”

title: d day veteran 94 gives
story: NewsD-Day veteran, , gives Theresa May kiss on cheek at memorial ceremonyFormer Royal Marine Robert William Yaxley, from Chelmsford in Essex, met Theresa May following a service at Bayeux Cemetery, and described how he "took her by the arms"ShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JUN NewsA -year-old D-Day veteran leaned forward and gave the Prime Minister a kiss on the cheek after meeting her in northern France"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA D-Day -year-old veteran gave Theresa May a kiss on the cheek at the th anniversary memorial ceremony in northern France.Former Royal Marine Robert William Yaxley, from Chelmsford in Essex, met Theresa May following a service at Bayeux Cemetery.Mr Yaxley described how after meeting May, he took her by the arms before kissing her face. He said: She came over and said apospleased to meet youapos. She said aposThank you for what you have doneapos. I kissed her - why not  It is not everyone that can do that. I took her by the arms and gave her a kiss on the cheek. She said aposOoh thank youapos.    The ex-commando was one of those who landing craft that reached Sword Beach on D-Day  years ago. Mr Yaxley said that after reaching France, he made his way through to Germany without a scratch. Len Williams, , was also an -year-old private with The Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders and landed on Gold Beach a few days after June . He said his meeting with Mrs May, who was accompanied by husband Philip, couldnapost have been more perfect. John McOwan, , from Peebles in the Scottish Borders, was a sergeant with the Royal Electrical Mechanical Engineers on D-Day. He landed on Sword Beach four days after June .    The Prime Minister said she was very pleased to meet me, Mr McOwan said. I said that I admire her very much and she smiled. This whole trip has been mind boggling. I shook hands with President Macron in Portsmouth, as well as Sheridan Smith. The service was very emotional. The tears were running down my face because it was so touching. He brought a cross for school friend Johnny Lowry, an RAF pilot killed during the Second World War. Mrs May also spoke to John Groves, , who was a guardsman with the Scots Guards and landed on Gold Beach days after D-Day. She told him: It has been a great pleasure to be able to see so many veterans here and be able to thank you for what you did.

title: d day veteran meets prince
story: NewsD-Day veteran meets Prince Charles  years after he met grandfather George VIAlfred Hicks, , served as an RAF sergeant during the Second World War and got to meet George VI - something Prince Charles himself never got the chance to doShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsCharles, Prince of Wales meets veterans after the the Royal British Legion Service of Remembrance at the Commonwealth War Graves Cemetery "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA D-Day veteran met and chatted to Prince Charles  years after he met the royalaposs grandfather, George VI. Alfred Hicks, , served as an RAF sergeant during the Second World War and was working with the Armed Forces Filming Unit when he was sent to document the Normandy invasion on June  . In the lead-up to the landings, the -year-old filmed the king, George VI as he inspected preparations in Portsmouth. Decades on, Mr Hicks shook hands with Prince Charles at the memorial ceremony marking the th anniversary of D-Day at the Commonwealth War Graves cemetery.    He said: The prince said I got a chance he never got, I got to meet his grandfather, and described the king as a lovely man, a really nice man. Mr Hicks, who landed at Sword Beach on the first day of the campaign, said: I wanted to get off at the beach and film the others coming in, but they then took us to the front line. Then we had to walk all the way back, it took us  hours. Charles also met -year-old Gerard Robertson, who had an unusual experience when he arrived on Juno Beach aged .    He trained with the Durham Light Infantry, but got separated from his colleagues after they landed on the beach on D-Day. Mr Robertson said: We got off the boat and I couldnapost find the company, and I never did find them. We ended up going up the beach with the Canadians. The following morning, after we found a ditch to stay in overnight, we found another company, the Engineers. Mr Robertson ended up sticking with the Engineers for the rest of his military career, and joked: The only reason I ended up with the Engineers was because I could fix a bicycle chain!   Prince Charles, was joined by Theresa May and other leaders paid tribute to D-Day troops at a moving Royal British Legion remembrance ceremony marking the th anniversary of the invasion. The cathedral service was held in Bayeux, the first major place to be liberated after the Allied forces invasion which was the largest amphibious invasion in military history and the beginning of the end of  the Second World War.The ,-strong congregation declared in unison: We shall remember them, before a two-minute silence as emotional tributes were held in France and the UK.  At the start of the service, Cardinal Marc Ouellet read a message on behalf of Pope Francis, who said D-Day was decisive in the fight against Nazi barbarism and paid tribute to those who joined the Army and gave their lives for freedom and peace.

title: ford workers in shock 1700
story: NewsFord workers in shock as , jobs lost in closure of car giants Bridgend plantThe -year-old South Wales ­factory’s closure in September next year was branded a new “hammer blow” to Britain’s motor industryShareCommentsByMark Ellis:,  JUN NewsWorkers leave the Ford engine plant near Bridgend, south Wales, following the announcement that it will close in September  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFord workers told of their shock as the car giant confirmed its Bridgend engine plant is to shut, with the loss of , jobs. The -year-old South Wales ­factory’s closure in September next year was branded a new “hammer blow” to Britain’s motor industry. Staff were informed in letters from the US firm – then sent home and told not to come back till Monday. Employee Tony Phillips said: “I’m losing my job after  years. We’ve been lied to by Ford, which said its UK plants weren’t going to close.” Colleague Mark Lendrum told of his “devastation”, adding: “South Wales will be like a ghost town.” Another, Tom Jones, said: “My dad and half my street work at Ford.  This is gutting.” Locals in other trades also told of their fear for Bridgend’s future. Barber Michael Hanlon said: “The plant’s closure will destroy our town.” The Unite union’s general secretary Len McCluskey called the decision “a grotesque act of economic betrayal”. He went on: “These workers and the community kept faithful to Ford through thick and thin.“ButFord think we’ll make it easy for themto walk away they can forget it. We’ll resist this move with all our might.”The closure will also hit workers in the industry’s supply chain, plus the UK economy. GMB regional organiser Jeff Beck said: “This announcement is a real hammer blow.” Ford said the move is not Brexit-related. It blamed factors including “changing customer dem-and” and a fall in petrol engine sales.Its European president Stuart Rowley said enhanced pay-offs would be offered to Bridgend workers – who were “great” and had “done nothing wrong”. Other car industry job losses this year include , at Jaguar Land Rover. Honda will shut its Swindon plant in  and Nissan will not now build the new X-Trail at its Sunderland plant.Insurance giant Aviva said it will axe , jobs over three years to save £million a year.Us chiefs pull the rug from under UK workers By Graham Hiscott THE writing was on the wall for Ford’s Bridgend factory when, in late , Jaguar Land Rover ended an engine making deal with the firm. But Ford has been slashing investment in the plant and shamefully never had a vision for its future. Bosses were yesterday bleating that they “explored options”. But like Honda at Swindon, Ford is pulling the pulling the rug out rom under its dedicated UK workers when the going gets tough. Bridgend is just another outpost for execs in Ford’s Michigan HQ. But it’s a devastating blow for those left behind.

title: kate middleton takes first salute
story: NewsKate Middleton takes first salute in surprise visit to military music eventThe Duchess beamed as she arrived at the Beating Retreat - a display of military music, horsemanship, fireworks and pageantryShareCommentsByAbigail OLeary:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsKate made a surprise visit to the Household Division Beating Retreat at Horse Guards Parade on June "Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailKate Middleton has taken her first salute in a surprise visit to a military music event this evening. The Duchess beamed as she arrived at the Beating Retreat - a display of military music, horsemanship, precision drill, fireworks and pageantry. The mum-of-three took the salute at the prestigious event, a role usually given to the Queen. More than  soldiers wearing ceremonial unorms took part. About , bystanders cheered as the duchess arrived and took her seat at Horse Guards Parade on Thursday evening.    It has taken place on House Guards Parade in Whitehall every year since  and raises money for service charities. Wearing a cream collared jacket, with her hair in a slick chignon, Kate smiled and spoke with soldiers who welcomed her to the event. It paid tribute to the th anniversary of D-Day by including a composition taken from The Longest Day, a  film depicting the Normandy landings on June  . Kate was the only member of the royal family to attend the event, with the Duke of Cambridge marking the anniversary at an event in Staffordshire earlier on Thursday.  The hour-long programme featured traditional military anthems, telling the history of regiments in the British Army. As well as bands from the Household Division, this year the military spectacular featured The Band, Pipe and Drums of the Royal Guard of Oman. Dame Kelly Holmes, Honorary Colonel of the Royal Armoured Corps Training Regiment, took the salute at the eventaposs first night on Wednesday. Beating Retreat is performed in front of St Jamesaposs Park across two evenings every year in the week preceding Trooping the Colour, the Queenaposs official birthday parade. Earlier this week, Kate attended the state banquet held for Donald Trump and Melania.   The  Duke and Duchess of Sussex  gave it a miss, as did  Jeremy Corbyn  and House of Commons speaker, John Bercow. Among the attendees, however there were several familiar faces - including  Rose Hanbury . Also known as the Marchioness of Cholmondeley, Rose is the woman whom the Duchess of Cambridge is claimed to have ordered Prince William to phase out out of their Norfolk friend set, according to  The SunPrior to a reported falling out, the Cambridges were said to have enjoyed double dates with Rose and her husband David Rocksavage who live nearby, close to Sandringham.    Yet despite rumours of a rt, Rose was in attendance and was sat just metres away from Kate. The former model and mother-of-three was pictured arriving at the event wearing an elegant white gown. Itaposs not knownthis means the pair have repaired any damage to their relationship.

title: mum who dropped perfume bottle
story: NewsMum who dropped perfume bottle on foot has leg amputated after begging doctorsGill Haddington pleaded with doctors at Royal Preston Hospital to amputate her leg after the injury caused her leg to swell up to twice its sizeShareCommentsBySamantha YuleMilo Boyd:,  JUN NewsThe -year-old was in almost constant pain "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum-of-two who dropped a perfume bottle on her foot had her leg amputated by surgeons after begging them to remove it. The seemingly trivial injury caused Gill Haddingtonaposs right foot to swell to twice its size, develop sore ulcers and turn in to the left, with her toes curling underneath. The pain in her foot was so intense she would go to AE screaming in agony. After two years she begged doctors to amputate her leg. Now she is finally pain free after having her right leg removed below the knee.    Gill was getting ready one morning in September  when she knocked the empty square-shaped bottle off a chest of drawers in her bedroom by accident. She said: When I first did it I cried out in pain, I lted my foot to look at it and it hurt so much I couldnapost put it back down again. Initially I thought I must have broken it - I wish I had. The -year-old, from Morecambe, Lancashire, was sent home from the hospital after X-rays and scans showed no break or injury. However, over time the injury got worse and her own GP advised that the pain condition Fibromyalgia she suffered from must be intensying the sensation.    When her foot swelled and developed ulcers - side effects of auto-immune illness coeliac disease - Gill really started to worry. All the while I was becoming a prisoner in my own home, said Gill. I was in constant excruciating pain. I could not walk at all. Gill had to rely on family, including daughters Natalie, , and Chloe, , to feed her and take her out for walks. I donapost think I slept at all at that time, she added. It hurt too much to be laid up in bed.    Instead I would sleep on the sofa with my foot propped on a box to keep it in position, any movement I made in the night would wake me. Sometimes the pain was so acute Gillaposs partner, construction salesman Pete Nisbet, , would take her to the hospital for help. She was finally diagnosed with chronic regional pain syndrome in May  - a condition with which a person experiences persistent severe and debilitating pain followed by an injury.    Gill said: I had already started talking about wanting my leg removed, but everyone couldnapost believe what I was saying. My leg was already dead to me, it was the cause of so much pain and unhappiness and I just wanted to get on with my le. I wanted to be able to walk again and to go swimming. I love open-air swimming. Gill was eventually referred to a specialist in February  who she begged to remove her leg. She said: The specialist didnapost want to do it at first, but he saw how much pain I was in and he relented. In a way, I am pleased the pain was so bad. He could see there was no turning back from what was happening to me. This was the only way out.    Within four months Gill was in surgery. Surgeons at Royal Preston Hospital removed her leg in May  from under her knee, to ensure that she was left pain free. Gill continued: As soon as I came round my partner said to me, aposI can see Iaposve got my Gill backapos. I felt so happy. After months of being a wheelchair undergoing physio and aftercare, Gill got her first prosthetic leg in September  and was beside herself with joy. As soon as I got it I said to Pete, aposletaposs go for a walkapos, and we walked along the promenade. It was wonderful to be up and about. I hadnapost walked for almost three years. The prosthetic isnapost perfect but I love it so much, having my leg removed was the best thing I ever did. I donapost regret it at all.    Eventually Gill felt well enough toto her swimming. She will swam one mile in the John West Great North Swim, at Brockhole-on-Windermere, in the Lake District, on Saturdayfor charity. She said: I love swimming, I feel free when I swim, nothing hurts. Itaposs fantastic.To sponsor Gill visit www.justgiving fundraising gill-haddington

title: paul routledge europe must not
story: NewsopinionPaul Routledge: Europe must not forget sacrice as we leave EUThe British people shed blood to liberate Europe - We went to them in their hour of needShareCommentsByPaul Routledge:,  JUN NewsopinionTroops landing on the Normandy beaches during the D Day invasion "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSeventy-five years ago today, British soldiers were fighting and dying in the Normandy landings. I was sitting up in my pram, oblivious of the great drama. But this was a genuine people’s war. Every family had a personal stake in the long, exhausting battle to defeat Nazi tyranny. My father was in the RAF in the Middle East, my uncle Bob was flying tailgunner in Lancasters, my guardsman uncle Jack was invalided out after Dunkirk. Even my teenage auntie Barbara was in the services. The British people shed blood to liberate Europe. We went to them in their hour of need. They should now repay that sacrice, by coming to us in our hour of need, enabling us to withdraw from the EU with dignity, friendship and close trading links.  Arrogant President Macron and mighty Chancellor Merkel owe the freedom their nations enjoy today to the Tommies who gave their tomorrows. They should remember that and act accordingly. More than a million American servicemen joined the invasion of France, many giving their lives far from home for a free Europe. Their sacrice is rightly remembered alongside our own. But it was galling to see President Trump, the Vietnam War draft-dodger, basking in publicity for the anniversary celebrations, with his piggy eyes on re-election to the White House next year. If “the Donald” had been around in , no doubt he would have found pressing business on the golf course, as he did in the s.

title: single mum dream baby after
story: NewsSingle mum has dream baby after undergoing IVF just one day after she turned Samara Davies decided to become a mother with help from a sperm donor after being diagnosed with endometriosisShareCommentsByLucy NotarantonioChris kitching:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsSamara Davies, , following the birth of her daughter Ailani "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young mother has thanked a sperm donor for her dream baby after she underwent IVF treatment a day after turning .Samara Davies, now , took the decision to become a single parent last year after being diagnosed with endometriosis, which can make it dficult to get pregnant. The teenager was advised to have a full hysterectomy by doctors after the condition left her bed bound and suffering from painful cramps. Samara, a part-time receptionist, was desperate to become a mum and after receiving the £, funds from her family she was able to seek help from a fertility clinic.    And after just one round of IVF, she was over the moon when her two-week scan revealed she was pregnant with her daughter Ailani, now seven-months-old. The stay-at-home mum, Portsmouth, Hampshire, said: I suffered with cramps since I was -years-old and it got progressively worse to the point I couldnapost get out of bed. When I was , I collapsed and was rushed into hospital which is when they discovered I have a cyst the size of an orange, but the pains continued even after it was removed.    The following year, I was bed bound from February until June []. I lost a lot of friends as they didnapost understand why I couldnapost hang out with them, I couldnapost even make it to the local shops. I managed to sit my GCSEs with special arrangements at school but was unable to continue in higher education as my condition worsened. I was told at -years-old that I will need a hysterectomyI want to improve my quality of le and it really hit me. Samara, who was diagnosed with endometriosis in , I have always been maternal since a kid when I used to play with dolls, I knew I wanted to be a mum so finding out I might not be able to have children was heart-breaking.    Although the doctors didnapost give me a timescale, I knew a hysterectomy was vital because even after two surgeries, the pain was still there and it was unbearable. I didnapost want to jump into a relationship then have a baby with someone I had just met, so IVF and a sperm donor was my only option. It was a strange process picking the father of my baby from a list of hair and eye colour, but I just matched the characterises to mine. I always knew I would have a baby one day but I thought perhaps I would have a boyfriend too, but I wouldnapost change it for the world, I couldnapost image my le without Ailani now.  Samara felt the best she had in years whilst pregnant as pregnancy is known to reduce the pain and, in some cases, shrink endometriosis. Since giving birth, Samara, who turned  in January last year, is now able to work part-time as the severe cramps have not ed. She adds: It was never an option for me to have a hysterectomy without a baby and my parents were completely behind me. When I was bed bound, I was wondering aposwhy me apos but now I am grateful because I have my daughter. IVF was really harsh on my body, but it was worth it, I loved being pregnant as the cramps and pain completely stopped. I have taken a dferent route to my other friends who went to college after school but I am a mum now and I donapost plan on missing a second of Alana growing up. I went through so much to get her here so I want to enjoy as much time with her as I can before I start working.

story: NewsHow many minutes, hours and days you work for free by cutting your lunch break shortIts something many of us do, but it all adds up - and could even cost youShareCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor:,  JUN NewsSo many of us dont take a proper lunch break"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNot taking your full, allotted lunch break is something so many of us do.Maybe it feels asthere are not enough hours in the day to get through your work. Aside from the fact NO ONE lies on their death bed wishing theyaposd worked more over-time, cutting your lunch break short could actually cost you.    A recent study showed how the average employee in the UK will take just  minutes of an houraposs lunch break. It doesnapost take a maths whizz to work out thataposs  minutes of your own precious time youaposre losing.If youaposre not paid through your lunch, then, according to Refinery  , that equates to working , minutes for free each year. story: NewsD-Day th anniversary: Normandy remembrance service honours British heroesThe D-Day cathedral service was held in Bayeux, the first major place to be liberated after the Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy in the Second World WarShareCommentsByChris kitchingLaura Paterson:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video theresa-prince-charles-join-d-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Charles, Theresa May and other leaders paid tribute to D-Day troops at a moving Royal British Legion remembrance ceremony marking the th anniversary of the invasion. The cathedral service was held in Bayeux, the first major place to be liberated after the Allied forces invasion which was the largest amphibious invasion in military history and the beginning of the end of the Second World War. The ,-strong congregation declared in unison: We shall remember them, before a two-minute silence as emotional tributes were held in France and the UK. At the start of the service, Cardinal Marc Ouellet read a message on behalf of Pope Francis, who said D-Day was decisive in the fight against Nazi barbarism and paid tribute to those who joined the Army and gave their lives for freedom and peace. D-Day veteran Kenneth Hay, who was just  when he joined the operation, read from the poem Normandy, by Cyril Crain, who also took part in the Allied invasion. Mr Hayaposs reading began: Come and stand in memory of men who fought and died.  They gave their lives in Normandy, remember them with pride. Mr Crain landed at Juno Beach in June , four days before his st birthday. He died in , aged . Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said after the service: It was a beautul and inclusive service in memory of people who died in Normandy and ultimately helped to defeat the scourge of fascism. He also paid tribute to the people of Bayeux who he described as being so welcoming during events also attended by Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt, Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry, as well as senior staff from the Army, Navy and Royal Air Force. Following the service, hundreds of people queued in the streets of Bayeux to clap and cheer D-Day veterans as they paraded from the cathedral to the Commonwealth War Graves cemetery.    There, dignitaries and veterans laid commemorative wreaths at the Cross of Sacrice at the site where more than , war dead are buried. Mrs May - who resigns as Conservative leader on Friday - gave a reading from the Book of Micah before the hymn Abide With Me was sung. D-Day veteran Ray Lord then read: They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old. Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. At the going down of the sun, and in the morning, we will remember them. The Last Post was played by the Band and Bugles of The Rles, followed by a two minutes silence.    D-Day veteran Alan Harris then read: When you go home, tell of us and say, for your tomorrow, we gave our today. Veteran Frank Baugh, , told a service at Bayeux Cemetery how he was a signalman on a landing craft that took  troops from nd Battalion Kingaposs Shropshire Light Infantry from Newhaven to Sword beach. He described how the troops landed in about ft of rough water under heavy machine gun fire at .am. The landing craft was hit and the number  troop space caught fire, leaving some badly injured and having to stay on the ship, but those who had been lightly injured followed their comrades, he said. They wanted to go with their partners and thataposs what happened, Mr Baugh said. My most abiding memory of that day is seeing our boys we had been talking to the minute before. They got cut down with machine gun fire. They would fall into the water, floating face down and we couldnapost get them out.  We couldnapost help them. That is my most abiding memory and I canapost forget it. Prime Minister Theresa May, the Prince of Wales, Duchess of Cornwall, Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt and First Minister of Scotland Nicola Sturgeon are among those attending the service. Earlier in the day, a lone piper played an emotional lament at the exact moment British troops landed on Gold Beach in Normandy on June , . Pipe Major Trevor Macey-Lillie, of th Regiment Royal Artillery , performed Highland Laddie as crowds gathered on the beach below him and lined the promenade, applauding his performance. The piper began the lament at .am local timeon the remaining Mulberry Harbour in the town called Port Winston, signalling the minute the invasion began and the moment the first British soldier landed on Gold beach in Nazi-occupied France. Before the cathedral service, Mrs May and French President Emmanuel Macron attended an inauguration ceremony for a memorial to commemorate more than , members of the British armed forces who died in Normandy in summer .The British Normandy Memorial, funded by the Normandy Memorial Trust, is being built on a hillside in Ver-sur-Mer, overlooking Gold Beach, one of the key sites for British troops during the Normandy Landings.  A sculpture created by David Williams-Ellis was unveiled marking the beginning of construction for the memorial depicting three British soldiers storming the beaches. Expected to be completed within a year, it will record the names of , members of the British armed forces who died in the D-Day landings and Battle of Normandy. Mrs May and Mr Macron laid wreaths at the foundation stone of the monument. Seven British D-Day veterans were accompanied by four children, including Sir Winston Churchillaposs great-great grandson John Churchill, to lay flowers in front of the sculpture. Addressing the audience, French President Emmanuel Macron said: I am honoured to stand alongside Theresa May today to launch construction work for the British memorial at Ver-sur-Mer.The British people have long dreamt of this memorial. He added: This is where,  years ago, on June , , almost , British soldiers landed in France to free the country from Nazi control. This is where young men, many of whom had never set foot on French soil, landed at dawn under German fire, risking their lives while fighting their way up the beach, which was littered with obstacles and mines.  He added: It is time to remedy the fact that no memorial pays tribute to the United Kingdomaposs contribution to the Battle of Normandy. He said the monument would also be a symbol of the ties binding France and the UK. He said: Nothing will break them. Nothing can ever break ties that have been bound in bloodshed and shared values. The debates taking place today cannot affect the strength of our joint history and our shared future. President Macron assured Mrs May of his friendship, adding: Leaders may come and go but their achievements remain. The force of our friendship will outlast current events. Speaking at the inauguration service, Mrs May said: Itaposs incredibly moving to be here today, looking out over the beaches where one of the greatest battles for freedom this world has ever known took place. And it is truly humbling to do so with the men who were there that day. Itaposs an honour for all of us to share this moment with you.  She added: Standing here as the waves wash quietly onto the shore below us, it is almost impossible to grasp the raw courage it must have taken that day to leap from the landing craft and into the surf despite the fury of battle... If one day can be said to have determined the fate of generations to come in France, in Britain, in Europe and the world, that day was June , . Paying tribute to those who made the ultimate sacrice, she said: They laid down their lives so that we might have a better le and build a better world. The ceremony concluded with a piped lament from Trooper Kurtis Rankin of The Royal Dragoon Guards, and Mrs May and Mr Macron then spoke to the veterans. Some  plus D-Day veterans gathered in the town of Arromanches for a series of events, including a Red Arrows flypast and a firework display. Members of the public queued up to thank D-Day veterans for their service during the Second World War. Sid Barnes, , from Norfolk, served in the Royal Army Service Corps and landed on beach by Arromanches on June . He s every year to the town and attends commemoration events.  This year visitors were coming up to him to shake his hand, with one man saying: Without you and everything you and the other veterans did, we would not be here. Mr Barnes said: People are coming up to us to say thank you. But I think aposthank you for what apos We just did what we knew we must do. It is nice to know we are valued though. He was enjoying the sunshine on the promenade with other veterans including Charles Burton, , who came over to Normandy as part of a wave of troops on the second day June  with the Royal Ulster Rles. Mr Burton said: Itaposs nice to take part to be here but itaposs very dficult as you remember the others who died. In the UK, a service of remembrance and wreath laying took place at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, with dignitaries including the Duke of Cambridge, who joined more than  D-Day veterans at a public service in Heroesapos Square. As a -year-old, Pixie Jenkins, a former Wren, helped drive troops and equipment to Newhaven Docks in East Sussex in the the build-up to D-Day and throughout the Normandy Landings. The -year-old, from Aldridge, near Walsall, West Midlands, was among a handful of veterans who travelled to wreath-laying ceremony. Reflecting on the anniversary, said: I think the men that went over were wonderful and I hope the younger people today realise how fortunate they are to have people like that.  I think so many youngsters today have forgotten about the men. They look at them and think apostheyaposre old men nowapos - to them theyaposre just old men. And theyaposre not, they are wonderful, wonderful men that went over. I salute them all. Prince William laid a wreath with a personal message reading: In memory of all those who have made the ultimate sacrice. We will remember them. William. In Portsmouth - a day after a national service attended by the Queen, Mrs May, US President Donald Trump and other world leaders - a veterans parade was held before a memorial service at the cityaposs D-Day Stone. Veteran Jimmy Ockendon, , wiped away tears during the service attended by thousands of members of the public who paid their respects during a minuteaposs silence. Mr Ockendon told the Press Association: It was very emotional, the main person I was thinking of was my uncle who went on the Hood, his we had died just beforehand and he left two young children and my father and mother adopted them. I was also thinking of my father. As well as wearing his own service medals, Mr Ockendon, from Portsmouth, donned those of his father, Sergeant James Ockendon, who was awarded the Belgian Croix de Guerre and the Victoria Cross for his role in the First World War.  Mr Ockendon, who was serving at the time of D-Day but not directly involved in the operation, said: We were just off France and I heard on the Tannoy what was happening. We didnapost worry much in those days, we just got on with the job. Mr Ockendon, who attended with his we Joyce, , attended the service after earlier this week naming a train The D-Day Story Portsmouth for South Western Railway in recognition of the th anniversary. In south-west London, Prince Harry attended Founderaposs Day at the Royal Hospital Cha where he met the Cha Pensioners and six veterans from the Normandy Landings. President Donald Trump and his we Melania met American veterans at Omaha Beach in Colleville-sur-Mer, where they were joined by Mr Macron. Mr Trump, who flew in from Ireland, told veterans: Our debt to you is everlasting. Today we express our undying gratitude. When you were young - these men enlisted their lives in a great crusade - one of the greatest of all times. Their mission is the story of an epic battle and the ferocious eternal struggle between good and evil.In one of the first events of the day, serving soldiers paid tribute to the heroic efforts of their Second World War brothers in arms at a ceremony marking the first key battle of D-Day.  Shortly after midnight on June , , soldiers landed next to bridges over the river and canal at Benouville. Capturing the two bridges, codenamed Ham and Jam, was a key part of the D-Day operation, as it hampered movement of enemy troops and enable the Allied forces to press forward from the beaches. Dropping on French soil minutes into D-Day, parachutists and gliders from the Oxford and Buckinghamshire Light Infantry and the Glider Pilot Regiment joined the Royal Engineers, who were towed across the Channel in -men Horsa gliders, pulled by bombers, before gliding to their small landing area with pinpoint accuracy from , feet. The bridges were captured after a battle lasting under  minutes in which two soldiers were killed and  wounded, including Herbert Denham aposDenapos Brotheridge, who led the troops across and was the first British soldier killed in action in the Normandy campaign. When mission commander Major John Howard transmitted the Ham and Jam code to signal their success it marked the first British objective to be achieved on D-Day. Three-quarters of a century on,  soldiers from their successor units The Rles and the Army Air Corps gathered at the bridge. The Rles held a ceremony at the Pegasus Bridge memorial to mark the moment the gliders landed, with a speech from Major Howardaposs daughter Penny. French politician Christophe Blanchet told the crowd: This bridge was to allow the liberation of France, and with it the rest of Europe. A recording of Major Howardaposs speech from a ceremony at the site  years ago was played before the Band and Bugles of The Rles led their troops across the bridge.  Rleman Peter Ramsden, of the Rles nd Battalion, spoke of his pride in following in the footsteps of D-Day heroes. The -year-old from Durham, and currently stationed in Lisburn, Northern Ireland, said: Itaposs a massive honour to march across Pegasus Bridge. As one of our regimentaposs most prestigious battle honours, it means a lot not only to the regiment but to the lads in the regiment as well. The officers and soldiers joined Arlette Gondree at for a Champagne toast at the cafe she owns next to the bridge, Cafe Gondree, in a tradition held since D-Day. The cafe, where she lived with her family, was the first home in France to be liberated by the British and Ms Gondreeaposs father dug up champagne he had hidden in the garden from the Nazi occupiers, to toast the British troops who freed them. Ms Gondree said: There were  Germans in the village, fortunately they never found daddyaposs hoard. But when the British soldiers dug out their trenches, my father asked them to dig it up. Thus the reason why the tradition of the Champagne is tied to the Gondree name, to this simple house, and this is what I do tonight to thank them all and to remember what they went through. The great grandson of wartime prime minister Winston Churchill, Randolph Churchill, paid tribute to those who took part in the D-Day landings. Itaposs remarkable to think that  years ago the heroes that gave us our freedom were coming up these shores, he told ITVaposs Good Morning Britain. With the veterans here today - and itaposs wonderful to see so many - itaposs wonderful we can honour them and their comrades that didnapost come back. They really did give their today so we can have a better tomorrow.

The huge display offers a rare, yet meticulously choreographed glimpse behind the curtains at the hermit state, which tightly controls access within its borders. Foreign tourists have been allowed to attend the annual spectacle, which features more than , performers and is widely seen as another cog in strongman Kimaposs propaganda machine. It is intended to boost patriotic morale and loyalty to the despotaposs family. The Kim dynasty has ruled North Korea since .    But the epic display is in sharp contrast to North Koreaaposs repression of its own citizensapos freedom of expression. Reports say Kim seriously criticised the games for their wrong spirit of creation and irresponsible work attitude. It comes after conflicting reports suggestion he may have ordered the execution of a diplomat integral to the Hanoi talks with President Donald Trump who failed to secure an agreement with the US commander-in-chief. Reports in recent days suggest he may still be alive. The suspension of North Koreaaposs games was confirmed by tourism agencies with access to the East Asian country.    Koryo Tours, a Beijing travel agency that takes foreign tourists to see the show, tweeted that the mass games was temporarily suspended. From June  there will be a pause for some days weeks while the show is adjusted before being launched again - we wait to see what will change and when it will restart - watch this space!The Sydney Morning Herald reports the regime charges as much as USper person for foreign tourists to attend. The newspaper approached the general manager of Koryo Tours who reportedly said he had no idea what features of the show had upset Kim, with another employee adding the display was similar to the previous yearaposs rendition. The manager also said no one in North Korea could confirm Kim had ordered the suspension as they were not allowed to speak on his behalf. However Young Pioneer Tours tweeted that the games had been temporarily halted due to Kimaposs dissatisfaction with the ongoing performance.    Rare opportunities for outsiders to visit inside the state are heavily chaperoned, and curious visitors are widely cautioned against touring there. North Korea is viewed as a serious nuclear threat in the ided peninsula, where Kimaposs regime is internationally criticised as a surveillance state and frequently accused of human rights abuses by other countries and watchdogs including Amnesty International. Watchdogs say children are put through months of gruelling train ahead of Pyong Yangaposs annual May Day shows.When the Mirror spent eight days inside secretive North Korea last year , the Pyongyang parade involved , military and civilians and , performers, many of them children.Kim was seen waving enthusiastically to the crowd during the spectacular.   American college student Otto Warmbier was imprisoned in the country in  after being accused of trying to steal a propaganda poster from a hotel.He was released back to the US the following year in a vegetative state and died a short time later. Last year a US federal court found the North Korean government liable for Warmbieraposs torture and death in a case the state did not contest.
